body_text.text: Overview of Slices
Below you'll find examples of each slice in action. To see exactly how it was done in Prismic, just open The Kitchen Sink Feature Article and look at how each section was built.
Slice: Text Block
The basic building block of all features. It's where you add all text the text that goes into an article.
Below is a sample content section filled will all the different headings, body text styling options, and link examples you can feature in a text block.

Slice: One Image and Text
A slice that allows you to pair a text block alongside an image. This slice gives ⅔ of the article container's space to the text, ⅓ to the image.
Setting up the slice
Add the One Image and Text slice to your document.
Click the slice label icon (the tag-like icon) located right to the name of the slice.
Select one of the four layouts.
Add your text content. Works just like the Text slice.
Text Position & Image Aspect Ratio
You can s
Left: Tall Image -- Text
Left: Wide Image -- Text
Right: Text -- Tall Image
Right: Text -- Wide Image
Pairing Content with the Image
If you choose a tall image layout, you can fit more content alongside the image; less when paired with the wide image.
Final Points
If you forget to choose a layout, the One Image and Text slice will default to the Left: Tall Image-Text layout.
If you forget to add an image, the text section will take up the whole width of the article layout, not the whole width of the page.
Heading 1 is disabled in this Text Section of slice for the same reason it's disabled in the Text slice: Heading 1 is the title of the article.

body_text.text: Slice: Two Images and Text
A slice that allows you to pair a text block alongside an image. This slice gives ½ of the article container's space to the text, ¼ to the image.
This particular One Image and Text slice uses the 'Left: Wide Image -- Text' layout.
Setting up the slice
Add the One Image and Text slice to your document.
Click the slice label icon (the tag-like icon) located right to the name of the slice.
Select one of the two layouts.
Add your text content. Works just like the Text slice.
Text Position & Image Aspect Ratio
You can s
Left: Tall Image -- Text
Left: Wide Image -- Text
Right: Text -- Tall Image
Right: Text -- Wide Image
Pairing Content with the Image
If you choose a tall image layout, you can fit more content alongside the image; less when paired with the wide image.
Final Points
If you forget to choose a layout, the One Image and Text slice will default to the Left: Tall Image-Text layout.
If you forget to add an image, the text section will take up the whole width of the article layout, not the whole width of the page.
Heading 1 is disabled in this Text Section of slice for the same reason it's disabled in the Text slice: Heading 1 is the title of the article.

body_text.text: Slice: Blockquote
A slice that showcases a quote in big styled text.
Setting up the slice
Add the Blockquote slice to your document.
Click the slice label icon (the tag-like icon) located right to the name of the slice.
Select one of the three layouts.
Add your quote and attribution (who said it, what context)
Layout Options
You can select from three available styles:
None: solid black background; white quote text
Light: light-color background image; black quote text
Dark: dark background image; white quote text
Pairing Content with the Image
If you choose a tall image layout, you can fit more content alongside the image; less when paired with the wide image.
Final Points
If you forget to choose a layout, the One Image and Text slice will default to the Left: Tall Image-Text layout.
If you forget to add an image, the text section will take up the whole width of the article layout, not the whole width of the page.
Heading 1 is disabled in this Text Section of slice for the same reason it's disabled in the Text slice: Heading 1 is the title of the article.

blockquote_text.text: Exploration is in our nature. We began as wanderers, and we are  wanderers still. We have lingered long enough on the shores of the  cosmic ocean. We are ready at last to set sail for the stars.
You have brains in your head. You have feet in your shoes. You can steer yourself any direction you choose.
Books are the quietest and most constant of friends; they are the most accessible and wisest of counselors, and the most patient of teachers.
